newsitem.title: UK: Britain, France concern on jailed China dissident.
newsitem.headline: Britain, France concern on jailed China dissident.

text.p: Britain and France on Wednesday expressed their concern at the 11-year prison sentence handed down by a Chinese court to dissident Wang Dan convicted of trying to overthrow the government.

"We are dismayed by the heavy sentence that has now been given to Mr Wang Dan. His is one of a number of human rights cases which we have raised with the Chinese," a Foreign Office spokesman in London said.
"We urge the Chinese to show clemency and allow Wang's early release," he said.

Wang, a 27-year-old former student leader, was found guilty of conspiring to subvert the Chinese government, sentenced to 11 years in prison and deprived of his political rights for a further two years, the Xinhua news agency said.
He had faced a maximum penalty of death and a minimum 10-year sentence.
He said Britain would be considering with its EU partners what further action to take. Britain hands its biggest remaining colony, Hong Kong, over to Chinese sovereignty next June.
France expressed disappointment at the jail term and urged Beijing to soften the sentence.
"Appeals for clemency and tolerance have unfortunately not been heard," Foreign Ministry spokesman Jacques Rummelhardt told reporters.

"France notes with disappointment today that China does not take account of European feelings and concerns," Rummelhardt said. "France joins its voice to all those requesting a revision of this judgment on appeal."

He added that "the harshness of the sentence seems as shocking as the judgment against Wei Jingsheng", the father of China's tiny, struggling democracy movement sentenced to 14 years in jail last year on similar subversion charges.
Wang, 27, told his family after the four-hour trial that he wanted to appeal.

France, seeking to foster ties with China as an export market despite worries about its human rights record, has angered Beijing this week by allowing a visit by Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama.
